iati-activity.description: The project objective is to strengthen the overall effectiveness and sustainability of Mozambique's protected area system, including financial sustainability, through working partnerships between private, NGO and community stakeholders.

result.title: Objective
result.description: Objective: Strengthen the overall effectiveness and sustainability of Mozambiqueâ€™s Protected Area System, including financial sustainability, through working partnerships between public, private, NGO and community stakeholders

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Financial sustainability scorecard for national system of protected areas

actual.comment: Approaching the target. 38% The Financial Scorecard was applied. There is a general change to the baseline, and a limited change compared to the past year, but some of the objective of the project will be achieved. In particular: ?Legal, regulatory and institutional frameworks? are in a good level; The level of Business planning and tools for cost-effective management is poor. The level will increase, as the ANAC Financial Plan is concluded, the ANAC Business Plan is in progress and two other consultancies on revenue generation/canalization mechanisms will be finalized until this year. In addition, ANAC is currently developing the regulations for the recently approved Conservation Law. All this tools will improve the legal and the institutional frameworks, as well as the operational activities in the ANAC and PAs system. The score of Tools for revenue generation by PA system will also increase for the same reasons.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Capacity development indicator score for protected area system

actual.comment: Approaching the target. Systemic: 49% Institutional: 49% Individual: 76% There are not significant changes comparing to the baseline and only marginal progress has been made. For systemic and Institutional level, the activities in progress will improve the scores as there are some changes in the ANACs management structure. For the individual one, the critical situation in Gorongosa is in part overpassed and actually some activities, useful to improve the indicators levels, has been developed. The results can be considered very good. This fact can be considered also a success story in the biodiversity conservation policies in Mozambique. With new Government, after 2014 elections, the management of PAs system was moved from the Ministry of Tourism (MITUR) to newly created Ministry of Land, Environment and Rural Development (MITADER). This has created an added value to the PAs system, as some of regulatory instruments were dependent to former Ministry for Coordination of Environmental Affairs (MICOA), which mandates now belongs to the same ministry (MITADER).

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 3. Total budget (including operational, HR and capital budget) (US$ per annum) for protected area management

actual.comment:
Target achieved.
The PAs System Financial Plan provided a significant number of analysis and financial information.
The total budget for the 2014 was of US$ 25.9 million
The total operating costs, budgeted for the current year (2015) are of US$ 30.7 million (including also private hunting areas, which is now accounted to ANAC as per new government structure within MITADER).

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 4. Number of protected areas in which the METT is adopted as a tool to monitor effectiveness of PA management

actual.comment:
Target achieved.
The BIOFUND has collected during the past months all the available METTs (applied during 2013-2014). 17 METTs are published on the BIOFUND’s website.
It would be useful applied again the METT in the final phase of this GEF Project.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: 1) Sustainability of the Protected Area System institutionalized

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 5. Financial plan for system of protected areas adopted by government

actual.comment: Approaching the target. The Financial Plan was concluded and it's expected that in the coming months the Government will adopt it.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 6. Achievement (%) of performance targets detailed in the PA agencyâ€™s Annual Performance Plan

actual.comment: The indicator cannot be assessed at this stage. The ANAC Annual Performance Plan was produced and is beginning to be implemented. A baseline for the performance of the PA agency was established. Now there are metrics for measuring performance, but at least one full year needs to be concluded for the project to be able to assess progress in this indicator. What is to be highlighted is the project’s role in facilitating the preparation of the plan.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 7. Number of protected areas with business plans that enable the sourcing of adequate funds for the implementation of PA management plan

actual.comment: Approaching the target. The PAs System Financial Plan collected the available information about the PAs Business Plans. 6 PAs have a Business Plan: Bazaruto, Limpopo, Quirimbas, Zinave, Lago Niassa, Ilhas Primeiras e Secundas (draft). Under this GEF projects umbrella, 3 Management Plans (Pomene, Marromeu, Magoe) will be produced. They will include the related business plans. Then, Bazarutos Management Plan and Business Plan are under revision.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 8. Ratio of human resource to operational costs in PA agency

baseline.comment: PA agency still to be established

actual.comment:
Approaching the target. The PAs Financial Plan and the ANAC Strategic Plan assessed this topic.
- Costs for human resources: USD 323,000
- Operational costs: USD 367,000
- Ratio: 46 - 53
For the current year, the provision (ANAC Strategic Plan) is the following:
- Costs for human resources: USD 0.5 million
- Operational costs: USD 1.3 million
- Ratio: 30 70

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 9. Number of protected area staff completing in-house specialized financial management training and skills development programmes

actual.comment: Making incipient progress towards the target. Specialized: 1 General: 2. The PMU is organizing a specific training course, in collaboration with the ANAC Human Resources office

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 10. Recruitment of staff to approved posts in the organogram of new PA agency (% of posts with staff appointed)

actual.comment:
Making progress towards the target.
55%
The ANAC (PA agency) should recruit 73 staff members.
Actually staff members (deployed, redeployed from other public administration offices, fixed aides and fixed consultants) are 40.
Some directors and chiefs of department were recruited last years.
It's important to underline that this GEF project does not contribute directly to staff recruitment.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 11. % of audit queries adequately resolved by PA agency

actual.comment: Still Not possible to report progress at this stage. The financial plan is under implementation. When audits are regularly carried out on ANAC’s finance, the project will be able to report on it. We report though on the audit exercises on PROFIN (this project), for which the target would be achieved. Four UNDP audit queries were addressed and resolved.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 12. Number of native tree species planted on the Gorongosa Mountain slopes

actual.comment: Target achieved.Jan to June 2015: 79,944, July to Dec 2014: 59,000. Total during the last 12 months: 138,944

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 13. Total area ( as a % of the original extent) of evergreen forest on Gorongosa Mountain (above 700m) deforested

actual.comment: Cannot inform the indicator. Due to continued security issues it has not been possible for the GRP staff to access the Mountain with the exception of small section close to Niankoukou and the Murombodzi waterfall. There have also been no overflights with a helicopter during this period. Consequently, it has not been possible to assess the situation with regards to forest clearing. It is planned to commission a new high-resolution (sub-meter pixel) satellite image around April-June 2016 for comparison with the 2013 image.

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 14. Number of agriculture clearings (more than 1ha in extent) in the Gorongosa Mountain (above 700m)

actual.comment: Cannot inform the indicator. Due to continued security issues it has not been possible for the GRP staff to access the Mountain with the exception of small section close to Niankoukou and the Murombodzi waterfall. Consequently, it has not been possible to assess the situation with regards to any new clearings for agricultural purposes. It is planned to commission a new high-resolution (sub-meter pixel) satellite image around April-June 2016 for comparison with the 2013

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 15. Cost of enforcement and compliance in the proposed GNP expansion area (USD/km2/year)

actual.comment: Data Provided by the Park Administration indicates for 208. Target achieved

indicator.title: Indicator 5
indicator.description: 16. Number of community-based rangers employed by GNP

actual.comment:
Approaching the target.
Total number of community-based rangers employed by GNP: 24

indicator.title: Indicator 6
indicator.description: 17. Number of wildlfires (larger than1 km2) in the Gorongosa Mountain (above 700m)

actual.comment: Baseline and target reconstruction would be needed because adequate data on this was not available at project start. Baseline and targets were established not very stringently. New data is available now. Yet, from all indications, progress is good, with room for improvement. A historical analysis of the NASA FIRMS data has now been completed for the main (historical) Park for the period 2000-2013. The average fire return interval is 3.2. years, which translates to 31% of the Park being burned every year. This is in line with Fire Return Intervals recorded for other large tropical savanna ecosystems such as Niassa. This analysis has brought up some methodological issues which will need to be considered in the analysis of the data for the Mountain. In any case, is reasonable considering that the indicator level is good, but can be improved.

indicator.title: Indicator 7
indicator.description: 18. Average monthly household income of the Canda, Sandjungira and Tambara communities (US$)

actual.comment: Indicator cannot be assessed. No updates to the indicator. Household surveys were not carried out, however, it is important to note that 20 hectares of coffee have been established on Mt Gorongosa that will lead to future income. In the interim there is inter row cropping that is providing improved household income. The project includes the planting of indigenous trees to support reforestation targets. The coffee project is not adequately represented in the current indicators.

indicator.title: Indicator 8
indicator.description: 19. Number of employed community members in reforestation activities and tourism ventures

actual.comment: Approaching the target. 79 (of which 51 are forestry workers , 24 are rangers and 4 are technicians)

indicator.title: Indicator 9
indicator.description:
20. Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool scorecard:
Gorongosa National Park

actual.comment:
Target achieved.
76%

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 21. Capitalization of BIOFUND by donors/funders (US$ committed)

actual.comment:
Approaching the target.
Currently US$ 15,856,900 Million invested in the endowment fund. Expected to increase at least to US$ 22 million by the end of 2015, with additional donations.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 22. Annual revenues generated from protected areas user fees (including concession income) (US$)

baseline.comment:
US$1,680,992
Of this amount, only 64% is however retained for re-investment in protected areas (20% is returned to the provincial state budget and 16% distributed to local communities)

target.comment:
more than $2.5m
No annual adjustment for CPI

actual.comment: Approaching the target. US$ 1,338,337 (Revenue generated by the conservation areas, managed by the ANAC) With an addition amount of US$ 576,923, provided by the area of S. SebastiÃ£o (managed by a private operator)

indicator.title: Indicator 3
indicator.description: 23. Average annual revenue generated for protected areas from biodiversity offsets and carbon sequestration (US$)

actual.comment:
No changes to the baseline.
Blue Forest project was approved and has been undertaken by WWF with a budget of 425,000 USD for 4 years, 2014 – 2017. This project will support the achievement of project objectives, but it's not possible to achieve the target level, has the implementation actions will produce effective results after the end of this GEF project.

indicator.title: Indicator 4
indicator.description: 24. Annual average value of grants from BIOFUND to protected areas for operational and capital development costs

actual.comment: No changes to the baseline. BIOFUND is still in the capitalization phase, having just received the first funds for investments at the end of 2014, beginning of 2015. Revenues from the current endowment capitalization (US$ 500 000,00 per year) are estimated to be available from 2017 onwards, just after the expected time of closing of this project.

iati-activity.title: Adaptation in the Coastal Zones of Mozambique
iati-activity.description: The project has 2 Outcomes relating to the development of adaptive capacity to manage the effects of climate change on coastal resources. The project has 4 indicators and targets that measure adaptive capacity, in line with the GEF V Results Framework.

iati-activity.title: Adaptation in the Coastal Zone
iati-activity.description: The project will tackle barriers in relation to weak inter-sectoral policy coordination and development, low institutional and individual capacity to plan for climate change, and financial constraints.

location.name: Pemba
location.activity-description: Creation of community resilience and livelihood

result.title: Objective
result.description: To develop capacity of communities living in the coastal zone to manage climate change risks

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: % of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)

baseline.comment: Coastal communities lack the resources or support to strengthen their resilience against CC induced hazards.

target.comment: At the end of the project 50% of men and women have declared ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender).

actual.comment: Substantial progress has been made in regards to the Development Objectives. At the moment 14% of men and 9% of women declare ownership of the adaptation processes.

result.title: Outcome 1
result.description: Climate change risks to coastal zones integrated into key decision-making process and managed at community level as well as sub-national and national government level

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description: 1. Capacity Perception Index

baseline.comment:
Capacity Assessment score: 2.45/5
The project will improve the capacity of local Govt to i) to engage in stakeholder dialogue to understand needs and priorites for CCA ii) the capacity to develop a climate risk problem analysis and create a vision and mandate for CCA initiatives iii) to formulate policy and strategy on CCA initiatives 4) the capacity to budget, manage and implement CCA initiatives.
The scorecard uses 10 indicators deemed by stakeholders to be the most important capacity gaps

actual.comment: Continued support has been provided to key government institutions at the sub-national level in integration of CCA initiatives in their planning cycle. These included key partnerships with the National Disaster Management Institute, Municipality of Pemba, District Authorities of Pebane and Inharrime, National Meteorological Institute, Agricultural Research Institute, the Center for Sustainable Development, Higher School of Marine Sciences, Eduardo Mondlane University, Marine Administration, and the recently established Climate Change Knowledge Center at the Academy of Science of Mozambique. Initial training (in GIS and GPS usage) and data collection have been undertaken in the three project sites (Pemba, Pebane, and Zavora) for development of CC risk maps/profiles to further inform the planning system. Climate information systems have been improved since project inception, to support incorporation of CC risks into decision-making and planning.

indicator.title: Indicator 2
indicator.description: 2. Number and type of targeted institutions with increased adaptive capacity to minimise exposure to climate variability

baseline.comment:
The Institutional Capacity Assessment developed during PPG phase, suggests that
local authorities have low capacity to carry out a range of functions in relation to CCA policy and investment planning ranging from data analysis, developing CC risk profiles, to holding stakeholder consultations on community preferences, to using and information to inform policies, strategies and investment plans.

target.comment: At the end of the project 10 local government institutions have been trained in CC adaptation and SLR, and coastal erosion risk management and; at least one decision-maker from the key institutions made use of improved climate and vulnerability information in their coastal adaptation policies.

actual.comment: In total 74 sub-national government officials were trained in different subject areas, disaggregated as the following per specialized subjects: (i) GIS and GPS usage and climate information data collection for climate risk mapping, in total 17 government officials at the subnational level were trained, being 9 women and 12 men; (ii) climate smart agriculture practices, including adequate cropping pattern, seasoning, cultivars selection, among innovative practices, (23 district agricultural technicians at the 3 project sites (only 1 women from Inharrime)); and (iii) climate information translation and broadcast (34 local radio operators were trained, being 6 women and 28 men). The 7 Local Disaster Risk Management Committees created and equipped last year were trained on meteorological information translation, vulnerability reduction techniques and disaster prevention measures by the National Disaster Management Institute (being 6 women and 28 men). These committees are now contributing to government efforts at the local level in dissemination and gradually raising awareness in their own communities. Overall, more than 15 institutions are active project stakeholders, mainly government institutions where project activities are directly contributing to the awareness with regard to their function towards CCA, policy-making and climate resilient public investment.

result.title: Outcome 2
result.description: Adaptive capacity of coastal communities improved and coastal zone resilience to climate change enhanced.

indicator.title: Indicator 1
indicator.description:
1. % of targeted population affirming ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender)
2. % change in income generation in targeted area given existing and projected climate change.
3. % of population with access to improved flood and drought management, disaggregated by gender.

baseline.comment:
The VCA consultations during the PPG phase have shown that though aware of their vulnerability and that of the surrounding ecosystem, farmers, fishermen and all those whose livelihoods are affected by CC induced hazards, at the district and community level, have no financial resources and knowledge for resilience decision making in the face of droughts and floods.
The coastal management expert report revealed that there is currently no protection measures being undertaken by communities against sea level rise and storm surges.

target.comment:
At the end of the project 50% of men and women in the selected project sites have declared ownership of adaptation processes (disaggregated by gender).
By the end of the project, 50% of households in the pilot sites have increased their income by 50%.
50% of households have improved flood and drought management.

actual.comment: Adaptation measures have been validated and prioritized at the community level and technical partners, increasing ownership of adaptation process. Community investment plans have been prepared, submitted and approved by the Investment committee. Access to finance and training Inhambane: 5 demonstration fields in place (SDAE), working with same number of 12-15 members group, with 98% women 1 women’s group (5 People) trained and equipped for chicken production, and received in-kind loan - chicks and food (from FDM - hired microfinance service provider for this project site) 1 women’s group organized and trained for swine production and building pigpen (FDM) This represents innovative production technology into low productivity agricultural and breeding practices. For the other two project sites, Cabo Delgado and Zambezia, no activity reported for community training. Microfinance institutions have been hired and started to work in all communities. In Inharime (Inhambane province): - FDM was contracted. Diagnostic study realized; - Staff trained in saving and credit group methodology and 1 staff hired to work full time in Sihane community; - 6 savings and credit groups trained and active, saved 64.115 Mts; - 2 groups being prepared for in-kind loans for chicken & amp; swine production. All participants (SCG, Production groups) receiving business training and financial education. In Pemba (Cabo Delgado province): - CCOM was contracted. To date, 20 credit officers were trained to work in the 3 communities and in their production areas (out of town). - 3 service centers have been established. - A specialized institution hired by MFI to train its staff in the savings and credit group methodology. Training ongoing, with first groups to be formed by the end of July 2015. - 14 solidarity groups received loan (70 people) for MZN 455,000.00 - 33 individuals loans provided (6 Women = 18%) for MZN 1.36 Million - Total value of loans: MZN 1.815 Million of which 265,000.00 already paid back (5 ind. & 1 group) - All loans for small business petty trade that will contribute to households income. - All beneficiaries received training in business skills.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
Selected indicators:
Indicator 1: Number of good practices in local governance issues documented
Indicator 2: Number of district producing performance monitoring reports based on the District Performance Monitoring System put in place by the Government (SmoDD)
Indicator 3: Number of Districts with monitoring reports on their Socio-Economic Plans that include cross-cutting issues.
Indicator 4: Number of District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards
Indicator 5: Number of District Strategic Development Plans meeting “good” quality standards when assessed using the criteria defined by the Quality Assessment Manual of the Government.
Indicator 6: Number of District Strategic Development Plans which include cross-cutting issues

baseline.comment:
Indicator 1: 0
Indicator 2: 33
Indicator 3: 0
Indicator 4: 7
Indicator 5: 0
Indicator 6: 9

target.comment:
Indicator 1: 15
Indicator 2: 96
Indicator 3: 24
Indicator 4: 38
Indicator 5: 27
Indicator 6: 40

actual.comment:
Indicator 1: 12 good practices in local governance issues documented and 4 under finalization
Indicator 2: 128 districts producing performance monitoring reports based on the District Performance Monitoring System put in place by the Government (SMoDD)
Indicator 3: 37 Districts with monitoring reports on their Socio-Economic Plans that include cross-cutting issues.
Indicator 4: 37 District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards
Indicator 5: 24 District Strategic Development Plans meeting “good” quality standards when assessed using the criteria defined by the Quality Assessment Manual of the Government.
Indicator 6: 25 District Strategic Development Plans which include cross-cutting issues

target.comment:
Indicator 1: 22
Indicator 2: 128
Indicator 3: 36
Indicator 4: 49
Indicator 5: 44
Indicator 6: 49

actual.comment:
Indicator 1: 18 good practices in local governance issues documented and additional 8 under finalization
Indicator 2: 128 districts producing performance monitoring reports based on the District Performance Monitoring System put in place by the Government (SmoDD)
Indicator 3: 41 Districts with monitoring reports on their Socio-Economic Plans that include cross-cutting issues.
Indicator 4: 43 District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards
Indicator 5: 32 District Strategic Development Plans meeting “good” quality standards when assessed using the criteria defined by the Quality Assessment Manual of the Government.
Indicator 6: 36 District Strategic Development Plans which include cross-cutting issues

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description:
1.1. % of field visits report recommendations implemented 1.2. % of evaluation recommendations implemented
2.1. Number of country programme board meetings organized
3.1 Timeliness of annual audit 3.2. % of audit recommendation implemented
4.1. % of IP participation in NIM manual training
5.1. % of country programme delivery rate 5.2. Quality of M&E database

baseline.comment:
1. 1. 80% 1. 2. (TbD)
2.1 (in 2011)
3.1. All submitted by end April 3.2. 70%
4.1. 40%
5.1. 75% 5.2. M&E database established

target.comment:
AWP 2014 expected result 1 - The country programme monitored and evaluated according to its efficiency, effectiveness, relevance and sustainability. Indicators and targets: 1. % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2014 Expected result 2. The coordination capacity of MINEC enhanced in implementation of the country programme Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2
2014 AWP Expected result 3. Annual NIM/NGO audit exercise compelted on time. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2014 AWP expected result 4 Technical capacity of implementing partners and UNDP country office staff strengthened in RBM/PME. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%.
2014 AWP expected result 5 Institutional capacities of MINEC and UNDP maintained in support of the effective delivery of the country programme. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.

actual.comment:
AWP 2014 expected result 1. Indicator and target: % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95% 2014 report: The 2014 field visit report was elaborated jointly (MINEC-UNDP) and contained 7 recommendations. As most of the recommendations were strategic recommendations such as promoting coordination and synergies among projects, prioritize capacity building in some areas, reflect on possible value chains, it is difficult to assess if they were implemented or not. However, it is possible to say that all the recommendations are under implementation internally within the CO and with the IPs.
2014 Expected result 2. Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2 2014 report: Target met . 2 Programme Boards held in 2014 at MINEC.
2014 AWP Expected result 3. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90% 2014 report: 1. Target met. All 2013 FY audit reports were submitted by the deadline. 2. Target not met. Based on the OAI review conducted on the 2013 FY audit exercise, 75% of the recommendations were implemented or under implementation.
2014 AWP expected result 4. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%. 2014 report: NIM training conducted in February 2014 with high participation from implementing partners. The average participation from IP representative for the 2 days: 70 people which is considered very high.
2014 AWP expected result 5 Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.
2014 report: 1. Target not met. Country Programme delivery is expected to be around 73% for 2014. 2. Target met. The M&E analysis was conducted as part of the annual reporting process, including at Country Programme level.

target.comment:
AWP 2015 expected result 1 - The country programme monitored and evaluated according to its efficiency, effectiveness, relevance and sustainability. Indicators and targets: 1. % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2015 Expected result 2. The coordination capacity of MINEC enhanced in implementation of the country programme Indicators and targets: 1. Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2 2. Number of MINEC staff trained on project management. Target: 3 3. Number of IP institutions staff attending training in RBM/PME/NIM. Target: 15
2015 AWP Expected result 3. Annual NIM/NGO audit exercise compelted on time. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2015 AWP expected result 4 Technical capacity of implementing partners and UNDP country office staff strengthened in RBM/PME. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%. 2. Number of IP institutions staff attending RBM/PME/NIM trainings. Target: 15 3. Number of RBM/PME/NIM trainings conducted in 2015. Target: 3
2015 AWP expected result 5 Institutional capacities of MINEC and UNDP maintained in support of the effective delivery of the country programme. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.

actual.comment:
AWP 2015 expected result 1. Indicator and target: % of field visits report recommendations implemented. Target: 95%
2015 report: 73% of field visits implemented - Comment: The 2015 field visit report was elaborated jointly (MINEC-UNDP) and contained recommendations at both strategic and project level. A total of 19 recommendations were implemented out of the 26 provided.
2015 Expected result 2. Indicators and targets: Number of country programme board meetings organized. Target: 2
2015 report: 1 Programme Board held in 2015 at MINEC.
2015 AWP Expected result 3. Indicators and targets: 1. Timeliness of annual audit. Target: All submitted by end of April. 2. % of audit recommendations implemented. Target: 90%
2015 report: 1. 2014 FY audit reports were not submitted by the deadline. 2. Target not met. Based on the OAI review conducted on the 2014 FY audit exercise, 89% of the recommendations were implemented or under implementation.
2015 AWP expected result 4. Indicators and targets: 1. Level of participation in RBM/PME training. Target: 80%.
2015 report: In 2015, due to Government re-structuring which affected the IPs staff of most of the projects, no RBM/PME training was conducted.
2015 AWP expected result 5. Indicators and targets: 1. % of country programme delivery rate. Target: 90% 2. Quality of M&E database. Target: M&E Analysis done.
2015 report: 1. To be confirmed at the end of 2015 fiscal year (Mid January 2016) 2. Target met. The M&E analysis was conducted as part of the annual reporting process, including at Country Programme level.

indicator.title: Output Indicator
indicator.description: Selected Indicators: Indicator 1: Number of Development Observatories held according to established standards Indicator 2: Number of Development Observatories where Civil Society has a common position Indicator 3: Number of District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards Indicator 4: % of women participating to District Consultative Councils Indicator 5: National progress reports on APRM produced

baseline.comment: Indicator 1: 5 Indicator 2: 1 Indicator 3: 7 Indicator 4: N.A. Indicator 5: National progress report on APRM report not available

target.comment: Indicator 1: 8 Indicator 2: 8 Indicator 3: 30 Indicator 4: 30 % of women participating to District Consultative Councils Indicator 5: National progress draft report on APRM produced

actual.comment: Indicator 1: 14 Development Observatories held according to established standards Indicator 2: 14 Number of Development Observatories where Civil Society has a common position Indicator 3: 37 District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards Indicator 4: 30% of women participating to District Consultative Councils Indicator 5: National APRM draft report not finalized

target.comment: Indicator 1: 11 Indicator 2: 11 Indicator 3: 45 Indicator 4: 30% Indicator 5: National progress report APRM produced

actual.comment: Indicator 1: 16 Development Observatories held according to established standards Indicator 2: 16 Development Observatories where Civil Society has a common position Indicator 3: 43 District Consultative Councils functioning according to established standards Indicator 4: 30% Indicator 5: National progress report on APRM finalized. The progress report will be presented by the President of the Republic at the African Union High Level Event in January 2016.
